news_summary: NASA's latest SpaceX resupply mission advances scientific research on the space station, while discoveries of unusual ripple patterns in Mars' sands offer promising insights for future human survival on the planet.
news_summary_fr: La dernière mission de ravitaillement SpaceX de la NASA fait progresser la recherche scientifique sur la station spatiale, tandis que les découvertes de motifs d'ondulation inhabituels dans le sable de Mars offrent des perspectives prometteuses pour la survie future de l'homme sur la planète.
news_summary_es: La última misión de reabastecimiento de SpaceX de la NASA hace avanzar la investigación científica en la estación espacial, mientras que los descubrimientos de patrones de ondulación inusuales en las arenas de Marte ofrecen ideas prometedoras para la futura supervivencia humana en el planeta.

articles.title: NASA Science, Cargo Launch on 33rd SpaceX Resupply Mission to Station
articles.summary: Following a successful launch of NASA’s SpaceX 33rd commercial resupply mission, new scientific experiments and cargo for the agency are bound for the International Space Station. The SpaceX Dragon spacecraft, carrying more than 5,000 pounds of supplies to the orbiting laboratory, lifted off at 2:45 a.m. EDT on Sunday, on the company’s Falcon 9 rocket […]
articles.content:
NASA’s SpaceX 33rd commercial resupply mission successfully launched to deliver supplies and science investigations to the International Space Station from Space Launch Complex 40 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Florida on Aug. 24, 2025. Credit: NASA

Following a successful launch of NASA’s SpaceX 33rd commercial resupply mission, new scientific experiments and cargo for the agency are bound for the International Space Station.

The SpaceX Dragon spacecraft, carrying more than 5,000 pounds of supplies to the orbiting laboratory, lifted off at 2:45 a.m. EDT on Sunday, on the company’s Falcon 9 rocket from Space Launch Complex 40 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Florida.

“Commercial resupply missions to the International Space Station deliver science that helps prove technologies for Artemis lunar missions and beyond,” said acting NASA Administrator Sean Duffy. “This flight will test 3D printing metal parts and bioprinting tissue in microgravity – technology that could give astronauts tools and medical support on future Moon and Mars missions.”

Live coverage of the spacecraft’s arrival will begin at 6 a.m., Monday, Aug. 25, on NASA+, Netflix, Amazon Prime, and more. Learn how to watch NASA content through a variety of platforms, including social media.

The spacecraft is scheduled to dock autonomously at approximately 7:30 a.m. to the forward port of the space station’s Harmony module.

In addition to food, supplies, and equipment for the crew, Dragon will deliver several experiments, including bone-forming stem cells for studying bone loss prevention and materials, to 3D print medical implants that could advance treatments for nerve damage on Earth. Dragon also will deliver bioprinted liver tissue to study blood vessel development in microgravity, as well as supplies to 3D print metal cubes in space.

These are just a sample of the hundreds of biology and biotechnology, physical sciences, Earth and space science investigations conducted aboard the orbiting laboratory. This research benefits people on Earth while laying the groundwork for other agency deep space missions. As part of NASA’s Artemis campaign, the agency will send astronauts to the Moon to prepare for future human exploration of Mars, inspiring the world through discovery in a new Golden Age of innovation and exploration.

During the mission, Dragon also will perform a reboost demonstration of station to maintain its current altitude. The hardware, located in the trunk of Dragon, contains an independent propellant system separate from the spacecraft to fuel two Draco engines using existing hardware and propellant system design. The boost kit will help sustain the orbiting lab’s altitude starting in September with a series of burns planned periodically throughout the fall of 2025. During NASA’s SpaceX 31st commercial resupply services mission on Nov. 8, 2024, the Dragon spacecraft performed its first demonstration of these capabilities.

The Dragon spacecraft is scheduled to remain at the space station until December, when it will depart the orbiting laboratory and return to Earth with research and cargo, splashing down off the coast of California.

Learn more about the International Space Station at:

https://www.nasa.gov/international-space-station

-end-

Joshua Finch

Headquarters, Washington

202-358-1100

joshua.a.finch@nasa.gov

Steven Siceloff

Kennedy Space Center, Fla.

321-876-2468

steven.p.siceloff@nasa.gov

Sandra Jones / Joseph Zakrzewski

Johnson Space Center, Houston

281-483-5111

sandra.p.jones@nasa.gov / joseph.a.zakrzewski@nasa.gov
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a successful NASA SpaceX resupply mission delivering scientific experiments and cargo to the International Space Station, supporting important research with broad benefits for space exploration and Earth applications. It highlights advancements in 3D printing, bioprinting, and medical research in microgravity, contributing to future lunar and Mars missions and improving health technologies on Earth. The story has clear substance, significant scope, and positive real-world impact.
articles.personality_title: NASA’s SpaceX Dragon delivers new science and supplies to the International Space Station
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – NASA and SpaceX work together to send supplies and experiments to the International Space Station (ISS) through commercial resupply missions. These missions help support research in space that can benefit future space exploration and life on Earth.

**What happened** – On August 24, 2025, NASA’s 33rd SpaceX resupply mission launched successfully from Cape Canaveral, Florida. The Dragon spacecraft, carrying over 5,000 pounds of cargo, lifted off on a Falcon 9 rocket early in the morning. It is loaded with food, equipment, and important scientific experiments, including ones that test 3D printing of metal parts and bioprinting of tissues in microgravity.

**Impact** – The experiments on this mission aim to improve technologies for future Moon and Mars missions. For example, studying bone-forming stem cells in space helps understand how to prevent bone loss for astronauts. Printing medical implants and liver tissue in space could lead to better treatments for nerve damage and blood vessel growth on Earth. The mission also includes a new test to boost the ISS’s altitude, helping the station stay in orbit longer.

**What’s next step** – The Dragon spacecraft will dock with the ISS on August 25 and stay until December. After that, it will return to Earth with completed experiments and other cargo. The data and results from these studies will guide future space missions and medical technologies.

**One-sentence takeaway** – NASA’s SpaceX Dragon mission is advancing space science and technology by delivering critical experiments and supplies that support exploration of the Moon, Mars, and improvements in health on Earth.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Dragon de SpaceX de la NASA livre de nouvelles expériences et fournitures à la Station spatiale internationale
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La NASA et SpaceX collaborent pour envoyer des fournitures et des expériences à la Station spatiale internationale (ISS) grâce à des missions commerciales de ravitaillement. Ces missions soutiennent la recherche en microgravité qui peut aider à l’exploration spatiale et à la vie sur Terre.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 24 août 2025, la 33e mission de ravitaillement de la NASA avec SpaceX a décollé avec succès depuis Cape Canaveral, en Floride. Le vaisseau Dragon, transportant plus de 2 200 kilogrammes de cargaison, a été lancé sur une fusée Falcon 9 tôt le matin. Il transporte de la nourriture, du matériel et des expériences scientifiques importantes, notamment des tests d’impression 3D de pièces métalliques et de bio-impression de tissus en microgravité.

**Impact** – Ces expériences visent à améliorer les technologies pour les futures missions sur la Lune et Mars. Par exemple, étudier des cellules souches formant des os dans l’espace aide à comprendre comment prévenir la perte osseuse chez les astronautes. Imprimer des implants médicaux et des tissus hépatiques dans l’espace pourrait mener à de meilleurs traitements pour les lésions nerveuses et la croissance des vaisseaux sanguins sur Terre. La mission teste aussi une nouvelle méthode pour rehausser l’altitude de l’ISS et prolonger sa durée en orbite.

**Étape suivante** – Le vaisseau Dragon doit s’amarrer à l’ISS le 25 août et y rester jusqu’en décembre. Ensuite, il reviendra sur Terre avec les expériences terminées et d’autres cargaisons. Les résultats guideront les futures missions spatiales et les technologies médicales.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La mission Dragon de la NASA et SpaceX fait progresser la science et la technologie spatiales en livrant des expériences et fournitures essentielles pour l’exploration de la Lune, de Mars, et pour améliorer la santé sur Terre.
articles.personality_title_es: El Dragon de SpaceX de la NASA lleva nuevas ciencias y suministros a la Estación Espacial Internacional
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La NASA y SpaceX trabajan juntos para enviar suministros y experimentos a la Estación Espacial Internacional (EEI) mediante misiones comerciales de reabastecimiento. Estas misiones apoyan investigaciones en el espacio que pueden ayudar a la exploración espacial y a la vida en la Tierra.

**Qué pasó** – El 24 de agosto de 2025, la 33ª misión de reabastecimiento de la NASA con SpaceX despegó con éxito desde Cabo Cañaveral, Florida. La nave Dragon, que lleva más de 2,200 kilos de carga, fue lanzada en un cohete Falcon 9 temprano en la mañana. Transporta comida, equipo y experimentos científicos importantes, como pruebas de impresión 3D de piezas metálicas y bioimpresión de tejidos en microgravedad.

**Impacto** – Los experimentos buscan mejorar tecnologías para futuras misiones a la Luna y Marte. Por ejemplo, estudiar células madre formadoras de hueso en el espacio ayuda a entender cómo prevenir la pérdida ósea en astronautas. Imprimir implantes médicos y tejido hepático en el espacio podría mejorar tratamientos para daños nerviosos y el desarrollo de vasos sanguíneos en la Tierra. La misión también prueba una nueva forma de aumentar la altitud de la EEI para que permanezca más tiempo en órbita.

**Próximo paso** – La nave Dragon se acoplará a la EEI el 25 de agosto y permanecerá hasta diciembre. Luego regresará a la Tierra con los experimentos terminados y otros cargamentos. Los datos guiarán futuras misiones espaciales y tecnologías médicas.

**Resumen en una frase** – La misión Dragon de NASA y SpaceX avanza la ciencia y tecnología espacial entregando experimentos y suministros clave para la exploración lunar, marciana y la salud en la Tierra.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm-toned painting of a sleek rocket ascending gently from a coastal launch pad at dawn, with a glowing, stylized space station orbiting above, surrounded by softly illuminated symbolic elements like delicate 3D-printed lattice structures and abstract cellular forms floating nearby to represent bioprinting and scientific experiments in microgravity.

articles.title: Strange ripples frozen in Mars’ sands could hold keys to human survival
articles.summary: Perseverance is exploring Mars’ sandy ripples, strange frozen waves that could reveal how wind still shapes the planet. Along the way it uncovered unusual helmet-shaped rocks, sparking new questions about Mars’ present and future.
articles.content:
On Mars, the past is written in stone -- but the present is written in sand. Last week, Perseverance explored inactive megaripples to learn more about the wind-driven processes that are reshaping the Martian landscape every day.

After wrapping up its investigation at the contact between clay and olivine-bearing rocks at "Westport," Perseverance is journeying south once more. Previously, attempts were made to drive uphill to visit a new rock exposure called "Midtoya." However, a combination of the steep slope and rubbly, rock-strewn soil made drive progress difficult, and after several attempts, the decision was made to return to smoother terrain. Thankfully, the effort wasn't fruitless, as the rover was able to gather data on new spherule-rich rocks thought to have rolled downhill from "Midtoya," including the witch hat or helmet-shaped rock "Horneflya," which has attracted much online interest.

More recently, Perseverance explored a site called "Kerrlaguna" where the steep slopes give way to a field of megaripples: large windblown sand formations up to 1 meter (about 3 feet) tall. The science team chose to perform a mini-campaign to make a detailed study of these features. Why such interest? While often the rover's attention is focused on studying processes in Mars' distant past that are recorded in ancient rocks, we still have much to learn about the modern Martian environment.

Almost a decade ago, Perseverance's forerunner Curiosity studied an active sand dune at "Namib Dune" on the floor of Gale crater, where it took a memorable selfie. However the smaller megaripples -- and especially dusty, apparently no longer active ones like at "Kerrlaguna" -- are also common across the surface of Mars. These older immobile features could teach us new insights about the role that wind and water play on the modern Martian surface.

After arriving near several of these inactive megaripples, Perseverance performed a series of measurements using its SuperCam, Mastcam-Z, and MEDA science instruments in order to characterize the surrounding environment, the size and chemistry of the sand grains, and any salty crusts that may have developed over time.

Besides furthering our understanding of the Martian environment, documenting these potential resources could help us prepare for the day when astronauts explore the Red Planet and need resources held within Martian soils to help them survive. It is hoped that this investigation at "Kerrlaguna" can provide a practice run for a more comprehensive campaign located at a more extensive field of larger bedforms at "Lac de Charmes," further along the rover traverse.

Written by Melissa Rice, Professor of Planetary Science at Western Washington University
articles.reasoning: The article reports on Perseverance rover's detailed study of Martian sandy ripples and rocks, advancing scientific understanding of Mars' present environment and potential resources. This knowledge has broad significance for future human exploration and survival on Mars, representing a meaningful breakthrough in space exploration with tangible benefits for humanity's future.
articles.personality_title: Perseverance studies frozen sand ripples on Mars to unlock clues for future explorers
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The Mars rover Perseverance is exploring the planet’s surface to learn how wind shapes its landscape today. Scientists want to understand not only Mars’ ancient past but also its current environment, which could affect future human missions.

**What happened** – Recently, Perseverance examined large, frozen sand ripples called megaripples at a site named Kerrlaguna. These ripples are about 1 meter tall and formed by wind-driven sand. The rover used its scientific tools to study the sand grains, the surrounding environment, and salty crusts on the surface. Earlier, Perseverance also investigated unusual helmet-shaped rocks that likely rolled downhill, sparking new questions about Mars’ geology.

**Impact** – Studying these inactive sand ripples helps scientists understand how wind and possibly water continue to shape Mars today. This is important because these features may contain useful resources, like salty minerals, which future astronauts could use to survive on Mars. The research also prepares the team for studying even larger sand formations later on.

**What's next step** – Perseverance will continue its journey toward a bigger area of sand formations called Lac de Charmes. There, it will carry out more detailed studies to gain further insight into Mars’ surface and resources. This ongoing research will support planning for future human missions to the Red Planet.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Perseverance’s study of frozen sand ripples on Mars reveals how wind shapes the planet today and helps identify resources for future explorers.
articles.personality_title_fr: Perseverance étudie les ondulations gelées du sable martien pour aider les futurs explorateurs
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le rover Perseverance explore la surface de Mars pour comprendre comment le vent façonne encore le paysage aujourd’hui. Les scientifiques veulent en savoir plus non seulement sur le passé ancien de Mars, mais aussi sur son environnement actuel, important pour les futures missions humaines.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Récemment, Perseverance a examiné de grandes ondulations de sable gelées appelées méga-ondulations sur un site nommé Kerrlaguna. Ces ondulations mesurent environ un mètre de haut et sont formées par le vent. Le rover a utilisé ses instruments scientifiques pour étudier les grains de sable, l’environnement autour et des croûtes salées à la surface. Avant cela, Perseverance a aussi étudié des roches en forme de casque qui ont probablement roulé en bas d’une pente, suscitant de nouvelles questions sur la géologie martienne.

**Impact** – Étudier ces ondulations de sable immobiles aide les scientifiques à comprendre comment le vent et peut-être l’eau continuent de façonner Mars aujourd’hui. Cela est important car ces formations pourraient contenir des ressources utiles, comme des minéraux salés, que les futurs astronautes pourraient utiliser pour survivre sur Mars. Cette recherche prépare aussi l’équipe à étudier des formations de sable encore plus grandes.

**Prochaine étape** – Perseverance poursuivra son trajet vers une plus grande zone de formations sableuses appelée Lac de Charmes. Là-bas, il mènera des études plus détaillées pour mieux comprendre la surface de Mars et ses ressources. Ces recherches aideront à préparer les futures missions humaines sur la planète rouge.

**En une phrase** – L’étude des ondulations gelées du sable par Perseverance montre comment le vent façonne Mars aujourd’hui et aide à repérer des ressources pour les futurs explorateurs.
articles.personality_title_es: Perseverance estudia ondulaciones heladas de arena en Marte para ayudar a futuros exploradores
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El rover Perseverance explora la superficie de Marte para entender cómo el viento sigue moldeando su paisaje hoy en día. Los científicos quieren aprender no solo sobre el pasado antiguo de Marte, sino también sobre su ambiente actual, que es importante para futuras misiones humanas.

**Qué pasó** – Recientemente, Perseverance examinó grandes ondulaciones de arena congeladas llamadas megaripples en un lugar llamado Kerrlaguna. Estas ondulaciones miden alrededor de 1 metro de alto y se formaron por acción del viento. El rover usó sus instrumentos científicos para estudiar los granos de arena, el entorno cercano y costras saladas en la superficie. Antes, Perseverance también investigó rocas con forma de casco que probablemente rodaron cuesta abajo, lo que generó nuevas preguntas sobre la geología marciana.

**Impacto** – Estudiar estas ondulaciones inactivas ayuda a los científicos a entender cómo el viento y posiblemente el agua siguen dando forma a Marte hoy. Esto es importante porque estas formaciones podrían contener recursos útiles, como minerales salados, que los futuros astronautas podrían usar para sobrevivir en Marte. La investigación también prepara al equipo para estudiar formaciones de arena más grandes.

**Próximo paso** – Perseverance continuará su camino hacia un área más grande de formaciones arenosas llamada Lac de Charmes, donde realizará estudios más detallados para conocer mejor la superficie y recursos de Marte. Esta investigación apoyará la planificación de futuras misiones humanas al planeta rojo.

**Conclusión en una frase** – El estudio de Perseverance sobre ondulaciones de arena congeladas revela cómo el viento moldea Marte hoy y ayuda a identificar recursos para futuros exploradores.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a serene Martian landscape featuring large, gently curved megaripples of reddish sand standing about three feet tall, with a sleek robotic rover nearby using its instruments to study the textured sand and scattered uniquely shaped rocks like a helmet-shaped stone, under a soft, muted sky with subtle dusty hues, evoking quiet exploration and discovery.
